intro: Alloplectus coriaceus, commonly known as the rough leaved dock, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often hairy surfaces. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils and can be found along roadsides, fields, and wetlands. Its leaves are broad, rough to the touch, and have a waxy coating, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense, greenish-white inflorescences. Alloplectus coriaceus is also known for its medicinal uses in traditional herbal remedies.
